APPLIED CATALYSIS A: GENERAL ELSEVIER Applied Catalysis A: General 165 (1997) 159-169 Interaction of methane with supported Pd catalysts studied by adsorption microcalorimetry and TPD/TPSR techniques Holger Dropscht, Manfred Baerns2'* Lehrstuhl fiir Technische Chemic, Ruhr-Universitdt Bochum, D-44780 Bochum, Germany Received 3 June 1996; received in revised form 3 May 1997; accepted 30 May 1997 Abstract The interaction of methane with the surfaces of silica-, alumina- and titania-supported Pd catalysts has been studied by means of adsorption microcalorimetry and temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) with hydrogen in a flow system at atmospheric pressure. For adsorption temperatures ranging between 300 and 700 K, a complete dissociation of CH4 occurred which resulted in the formation of C(ads) clusters of different sizes as well as graphitic carbon. The subsequent temperature-programmed hydrogenation of C(ads) mainly produced CH4 together with trace amounts of CzH6 and Call4. With an increasing number of Pd surface atoms, more C(ads) was formed upon contact with CI~; the reactivity towards hydrogenation was, however, not markedly affected. Compared to Pd/SiO2, the reactivity of deposited carbon to hydrogenation, the C2 yield and the C2Ha/C2H6 ratio were higher for Pd/TiO2 and Pd/A1203 catalysts, while the tendency for the formation of graphitic carbon was lower. 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. Keywords: CH4 adsorption on supported-Pd catalysts studied by TPD; TPSR and adsorption microcalorimetry: Dissociation of methane; Surface carbon hydrogenation; Influence of number of Pd surface atoms and of support type; Formation of C2 hydrocarbons 1. Introduction ported noble metals [12--6] has gained much attention in current research. From a mechanistic oxygen or carbon dioxide using, for example, sup- point of view, the adsorption of methane on the catalyst surface forms an important elementary step in both of the above-mentioned processes. Interaction of methane with supported Pd catalysts studied by adsorption microcalorimetry and TPD/TPSR techniques Holger Dropsch 1 Manfred Baerns * 2 Lehrstuhl für Technische Chemie, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, D-44780 Bochum ,Germany * Corresponding author. 1 Betriebsforschungsinstitut, VDEh-Institut für angewandte Forschung GmbH, Sohnstrasse 65, D-40237 Düsseldorf. 2 Institut für Angewandte Chemie Berlin-Adlershof e. V., Rudower Chaussée 5, D-12484 Berlin. The interaction of methane with the surfaces of silica-, alumina- and titania-supported Pd catalysts has been studied by means of adsorption microcalorimetry and temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) with hydrogen in a flow system at atmospheric pressure. For adsorption temperatures ranging between 300 and 700 K, a complete dissociation of CH4 occurred which resulted in the formation of C(ads) clusters of different sizes as well as graphitic carbon. The subsequent temperature-programmed hydrogenation of C(ads) mainly produced CH4 together with trace amounts of C2H6 and C2H4. With an increasing number of Pd surface atoms, more C(ads) was formed upon contact with CH4; the reactivity towards hydrogenation was, however, not markedly affected. Compared to Pd/SiO2, the reactivity of deposited carbon to hydrogenation, the C2 yield and the C2H4/C2H6 ratio were higher for Pd/TiO2 and Pd/Al2O3 catalysts, while the tendency for the formation of graphitic carbon was lower. Keywords CH4 adsorption on supported-Pd catalysts studied by TPD TPSR adsorption microcalorimetry Dissociation of methane Surface carbon hydrogenation Influence of number of Pd surface atoms Influence of number of support type Formation of C2+ hydrocarbons Reference [1] Saint-Just J. coredata.dc:description: The interaction of methane with the surfaces of silica-, alumina- and titania-supported Pd catalysts has been studied by means of adsorption microcalorimetry and temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) with hydrogen in a flow system at atmospheric pressure. For adsorption temperatures ranging between 300 and 700 K, a complete dissociation of CH4 occurred which resulted in the formation of C(ads) clusters of different sizes as well as graphitic carbon. The subsequent temperature-programmed hydrogenation of C(ads) mainly produced CH4 together with trace amounts of C2H6 and C2H4. With an increasing number of Pd surface atoms, more C(ads) was formed upon contact with CH4; the reactivity towards hydrogenation was, however, not markedly affected. Compared to Pd/SiO2, the reactivity of deposited carbon to hydrogenation, the C2 yield and the C2H4/C2H6 ratio were higher for Pd/TiO2 and Pd/Al2O3 catalysts, while the tendency for the formation of graphitic carbon was lower.
coredata.dc:title: Interaction of methane with supported Pd catalysts studied by adsorption microcalorimetry and TPD/TPSR techniques
